thread.title: Defensive-minded Utah Jazz open preseason with 90-71 win over L.A. Lakers
thread.title_full: Defensive-minded Utah Jazz open preseason with 90-71 win over L.A. Lakers | Deseret News

author: Jody Genessy
title: Defensive-minded Utah Jazz open preseason with 90-71 win over L.A. Lakers
text:
In some ways, Sunday’s exhibition-opening win over the Los Angeles Lakers was a microcosm of the Utah Jazz’s 2014-15 season.
More Coverage Jazz notes: Bad singing, dancing by rookies at luau Slo-Mo Rodney https://t.co/vwzkSHMoS7

— Utah Jazz (@utahjazz) October 5, 2015 Hayward to Gobert! #AlohaJazz pic.twitter.com/nMNYU9ZeaG 
— Utah Jazz (@utahjazz) October 5, 2015 “ I thought it was a pretty typical first game for us as a team, because we played solid defensively, which I expected us to do going in.”
Gordon Hayward
HONOLULU — In some ways, Sunday’s exhibition-opening 90-71 win over the Los Angeles Lakers was a microcosm of the Utah Jazz’s 2014-15 season.
They struggled early on.
They had offensive issues, including a rough 2-for-15 showing from beyond the arc and a combined 4-for-23 shooting for returning guards Trey Burke (3-9), Alec Burks (0-5) and Rodney Hood (1-9).
Veterans Derrick Favors (16 points, nine rebounds, one block), Gordon Hayward (11 points, nine rebounds, four assists) and Rudy Gobert (10 points, eight rebounds, one block) made solid contributions.
Trevor Booker hustled and got under the skin of an opponent (Roy Hibbert).
Their rookie point guard from another country showed promise, with the international newcomer this time being Brazilian playmaker Raul Neto instead of injured Australian Dante Exum.
And, true to form, their defense gave them new life.
“I thought it was a pretty typical first game for us as a team because we played solid defensively, which I expected us to do going in,” Hayward said. “Offensively, we were a little sloppy, not as crisp. For the most part, I thought we played well. We’ll start to get it on the offensive end.”
All in all, it added up to a satisfying, albeit sloppy, win over the Kobe Bryant-led Lakers, which the Jazz and their fans appreciate regardless of it happening in the postseason, regular season or preseason.
“I thought we settled in in the second half and made some plays defensively,” Jazz coach Quin Snyder said. “We had some guys that looked like they were enjoying playing.”
That was especially the case in the second half when the defensive-minded Jazz erased the Lakers’ one-time lead of 13 and surfed a wave of momentum to an easy victory at the Stan Sheriff Center on the campus of the University of Hawaii.
“The first half was kind of rough. We were missing assignments, missing a couple of shots,” Favors said. “In the second half, everybody got into a rhythm. Everybody got comfortable and relaxed a little bit more. We just played better.”
While the Jazz’s big men were their usual stifling selves down low, an unexpected source provided a defensive lift in this game in front of a pro-Laker crowd of 10,300.
The 6-foot-1 Neto was a pest on defense in his debut, notching four steals to go with his six assists. Of all of the newcomers — a group that also included No. 12 pick Trey Lyles and German center Tibor Pleiss — the 23-year-old Brazilian had the biggest impact in this win.
“I felt pretty good. I tried to do what coach say,” Neto said. “(Snyder) say, ‘Press the ball full court, make them feel uncomfortable.’ I did that. I hit some balls, and I get some steals.”
Neto ended up playing 20 minutes behind Burke, who go the start and finished with 10 points and three assists.
Because of Exum’s knee surgery, which will keep the Aussie out all season, the point guard position is one of the biggest question marks for the Jazz this season. But Snyder liked what he saw in Game 1.
“He’s taken pride in it. It’s something clearly that is a point of emphasis,” Snyder said, referring to Neto’s defensive thievery. “I thought Trey gave us that early in the game as well. If those two guys, if they can come in like that and kind of tag team and just compete on defense and make you feel them, that helps.”
Burks missed all of his field-goal attempts, but he made at least three sensational passes, had three assists and grabbed four rebounds. It was his first game since his 2014-15 season was cut short due to a surgery-requiring knee injury last December.
“It’s good to have Alec back on the floor. He just provides a threat going to the rim,” Hayward said. “When he’s attacking, he’s hard to stop. It’s good to have him back out there.”
Burks, who sat next to Hayward in the visitors’ locker room, smiled and chimed in as his teammate talked about his passing.
“Offense will come. I can score on accident. I ain’t worried about that,” Burks said. “I’m glad I’m healthy. It’s a blessing. I know what’s it like to be hurt. I felt great. After 10 months, finally to be out there was a great feeling.”
The 19-year-old Lyles, who was a freshman at Kentucky a year ago, made his first NBA appearance. He scored four points, including a strong baseline move that went from being a missed dunk attempt to a fortuitous layup make, and had one rebound in 13 minutes.
Pleiss, who played in Spain last season, hauled in seven rebounds and hit four free throws but didn’t take a shot from the field.
“I was impressed with the way Raul played. Jeff (Withey) did his thing. Trey had a nice play baseline. Tibor got rebounds and did stuff that he does,” Favors said. “ I was excited and happy for everybody.”
Bryant scored five points in his first game since undergoing shoulder surgery in January. He finished 1-for-5 shooting and didn’t play in the second half.
Reserve Lou Williams led L.A. with 14 points. The Lakers struggled more offensively than the Jazz, shooting 32.7 percent from the field compared with Utah's 35.7 percent.
Big man Jack Cooley, point guard Bryce Cotton, guard/forward Treveon Graham and small forward J.J. O’Brien were the only available Jazz players who didn’t get any playing time.
Utah will practice Monday before taking on the Lakers again late Tuesday (10 p.m. MT tipoff).
